PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to everyone; others may prove impossible for you to answer. You may wish to explain about having blank spaces, but it is desirable to give detailed or descriptive particular answers, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experiences of the pioneer past whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

OTHER QUESTIONNAIRES—

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already received one, and are willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Sask Archives will be sent to you.

Later data, some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

[X] All questionnaires

[X] Pioneer health conditions

[X] Pioneer social life, sports and recreation

[X] Pioneer education and churchwork

[X] Pioneer farming experiences

Preservation of Questionnaires—

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of our permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Officer,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

John Arthur Stewart, at Caren, 1908.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? To settle?

My younger sisters, to teach—perhaps a few friends.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

All sisters came to teach, now are in the province now, settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stand out in your memory which you would like to record?

The first teaching experience, and during the first fall of the school year I was called upon to take charge of a large house winter school, which dealt entirely with my own children on the prairie and valley at the actual time, meeting with a real child at 31. The Maizey-Camp. Being also afterwards called to a and teaching all, a little more of the valley, the only dwelling arms 10 miles west of the Zephyr valley, 21 miles on the plains road of the Zephyr valley, 21 miles north-west, and 10 miles from May 15 to Nov. 30.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, trading, church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Mostly traveled by buckboard or waggon.
20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

He came west in 1892.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation?

All sisters came to teach, none are in the province now, settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

The first teaching experience, and driving through the first fall of the flu epidemic on May 15th, 1894, after a long, severe winter, when death visited my schoolhouse on the prairie and carried off the actual teacher, Mrs. Smith, who afterwards died at 71. The flu was very prevalent with a real death rate at the school. Only one child was left among the sixty dwellers in the plains near the village of Valley. The nearest hospital was at Lumsden, 21 miles away. The nearest station, also near the town, was at Prole.
